04E2944A25994C3BAFB5CE55A4A84FDD.description: Communicating Communicate scientific ideas and information for a particular purpose, including constructing evidence-based arguments and using appropriate scientific language, conventions and representations

49AEA05BA2E049F884469BB475A649AE.description: Use knowledge of scientific concepts to evaluate investigation conclusions, including assessing the approaches used to solve problems, critically analysing the validity of information obtained from primary and secondary sources, suggesting possible alternative explanations and describing specific ways to improve the quality of data

C6764700AA9447FA9E83910838D7FCFF.description: Analysing and evaluating Analyse patterns and trends in data, including describing relationships between variables, identifying inconsistencies in data and sources of uncertainty, and drawing conclusions that are consistent with evidence

E5D38CF8A5BD46E88DD9E4CBA4CF6BDF.description: Recording and processing Construct and use a range of representations, including graphs, keys, models and formulas, to record and summarise data from students’ own investigations and secondary sources, to represent qualitative and quantitative patterns or relationships, and distinguish between discrete and continuous data

9C73E58B08BA4A0A8273A9004D764703.description: Select and use appropriate equipment and technologies to systematically collect and record accurate and reliable data, and use repeat trials to improve accuracy, precision and reliability

DD270731008B4A5FB1D8C8CFEF0F88BD.description: Planning and conducting Independently plan, select and use appropriate investigation types, including fieldwork and laboratory experimentation, to collect reliable data, assess risk and address ethical issues associated with these investigation types

599A62CDDF414B0DB6A000C77044A4CA.description: Science Inquiry Skills Questioning and predicting Formulate questions or hypotheses that can be investigated scientifically, including identification of independent, dependent and controlled variables

3C69B0F2A4744224AB27CE006290FC5D.description: The description and explanation of the motion of objects involves the interaction of forces and the exchange of energy and can be described and predicted using the laws of physics

1A1EC135C2154F3BAB5A27AC05CED91B.description: Energy flow in Earth’s atmosphere can be explained by the processes of heat transfer

93D3E454AF5E4B848B5CA691E52F2884.description: The interaction of magnets can be explained by a field model; magnets are used in the generation of electricity and the operation of motors

E42AE4A9E8E84AAE8F2EBA9F8FBBD64E.description: Physical sciences Electric circuits can be designed for diverse purposes using different components; the operation of circuits can be explained by the concepts of voltage and current

DFF22FF393D64A73A5A7A40DB2827DC7.description: The Universe contains features including galaxies, stars and solar systems; the Big Bang theory can be used to explain the origin of the Universe

33E578C15C5B4F73982336728700E037.description: Global systems, including the carbon cycle, rely on interactions involving the atmosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere and lithosphere

45D15C6982554C37979CC5DDCF67E289.description: Earth and space sciences The theory of plate tectonics explains global patterns of geological activity and continental movement

1FED8D76A4F24A79B27DA0EB5805ECD2.description: Chemical reactions, including combustion and the reactions of acids, are important in both non-living and living systems and involve energy transfer

ECCAA7F0A0CF496E82316D08AB192C28.description: Different types of chemical reactions are used to produce a range of products and can occur at different rates; chemical reactions may be represented by balanced chemical equations

EBE93AB48F1E49F09BC09E8347D874EA.description: Chemical reactions involve rearranging atoms to form new substances; during a chemical reaction mass is not created or destroyed

6676AA438B8B41A5A2ACBCF430E74729.description: The atomic structure and properties of elements are used to organise them in the periodic table

30B7983D942E4A35B4A87C9687F1826E.description: Chemical sciences All matter is made of atoms which are composed of protons, neutrons and electrons; natural radioactivity arises from the decay of nuclei in atoms

32F4CA8E86714D03A0944ECD3AB9DEB3.description: Ecosystems consist of communities of interdependent organisms and abiotic components of the environment; matter and energy flow through these systems

946EFAF483FF47139C7D54A849A235A2.description: The theory of evolution by natural selection explains the diversity of living things and is supported by a range of scientific evidence

E12081ACABBE4273964FD6AE84F88593.description: The transmission of heritable characteristics from one generation to the next involves DNA and genes

E915E3758D114F988EFF03A7DA22226E.description: An animal’s response to a stimulus is coordinated by its central nervous system (brain and spinal cord); neurons transmit electrical impulses and are connected by synapses

59C8A1C6579E4E008A97FCF7293FC535.description: Multicellular organisms rely on coordinated and interdependent internal systems to respond to changes to their environment

246D15BF60E94A748CD65CF294BC3979.description: The values and needs of contemporary society can influence the focus of scientific research

826FC82410EE4DE4A1018E369D995FD7.description: Advances in scientific understanding often rely on developments in technology and technological advances are often linked to scientific discoveries

5BC814F99E4C462D91CC7F77A65916FF.description: Scientific understanding, including models and theories, are contestable and are refined over time through a process of review by the scientific community
